question.title: Will the International Monetary Fund announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not exceed $400 million, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the International Monetary Fund not announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund does not officially announce one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must not be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) or not be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must not be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, or must be continuations of previously announced commitments. If such an announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments exceeds $400 million, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the International Monetary Fund reveal new financial pledges exceeding $400 million by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund officially discloses one or more new financial pledges that together surpass $400 million. The disclosures must occur through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be covered by at least two credible news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The financial pledges must represent new initiatives or substantial expansions of current programs, rather than continuations of previously made commitments. If no such disclosure occurs by the resolution date, or if the total of new financial pledges does not exceed $400 million, the inquiry resolves as negative.

question.title: Will either the Philippine government enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms or the IMF announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If neither of these conditions is met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither the Philippine government enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms nor the IMF announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if neither of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If either of these conditions is met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Philippine authorities either implement a closure of online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities or will the IMF declare new financial commitments exceeding $400 million by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if at least one of the following happens by July 31, 2024: (a) There are verified accounts indicating that the Philippine authorities have effectively carried out a closure of online trading platforms run by Chinese entities within the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two credible international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and must involve official governmental actions resulting in the termination of operations for a considerable number of these trading platforms. 'Considerable' in this case means at least 50% of the known Chinese-operated online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The closure must stem from government policy or directive, rather than voluntary shutdowns or market conditions. (b) The International Monetary Fund formally announces one or more new financial commitments that together exceed $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The financial commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, and not merely continuations of previously disclosed commitments. If neither of these conditions is satisfied by the resolution date, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the FDA approve MDMA as a therapy for PTSD by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. For a positive resolution, the approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically be for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD, not for any other condition or use. If no such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly rejects or delays the approval beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will the FDA not approve MDMA as a therapy for PTSD by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) does not officially approve MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. For a positive resolution, the approval must not be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA or reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically not be for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD, or for any other condition or use. If such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA does not explicitly reject or delay the approval beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will MDMA receive FDA endorsement as a treatment for PTSD before the end of August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) formally endorses MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) as a treatment for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) on or before August 31, 2024. For a positive outcome, this endorsement must be validated through an official statement from the FDA and reported by a minimum of two reliable news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or leading national newspapers). The endorsement must specifically pertain to MDMA's application in treating PTSD, excluding any other conditions or uses. If such an endorsement is not granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly denies or postpones the endorsement past August 31, 2024, the inquiry will conclude as NO.

question.title: Will Mexican authorities officially declare the dismantling of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) make an official public declaration stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources). The declaration should indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. Mere arrests of individual members or partial disruptions to the cartel's activities do not qualify for a YES resolution. If no such official declaration meeting these criteria is made by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will Mexican authorities not officially declare the dismantling of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) do not make an official public declaration stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must not be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources). The declaration should not indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. Mere arrests of individual members or partial disruptions to the cartel's activities do not qualify for a NO resolution. If such an official declaration meeting these criteria is made by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as YES.

para_P.title: Will the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel be officially declared dismantled by Mexican authorities before July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, Mexican authorities (including federal law enforcement or senior government officials) release an official public statement confirming that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The announcement must be covered by at least two reliable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or prominent Mexican news outlets). The statement should reflect a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership, operations, or its ability to operate as a unified criminal group. Simple arrests of individual members or minor disruptions in the cartel's activities do not qualify for a YES resolution. If no such official statement fulfilling these conditions is issued by July 31, 2024, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will either the FDA approve MDMA as a therapy for PTSD by August 2024 or Mexican authorities declare the dismantling of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following occurs: (a) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. The approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically be for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD, not for any other condition or use. If no such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly rejects or delays the approval beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. (b) Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) make an official public declaration by July 31, 2024, stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources). The declaration should indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. Mere arrests of individual members or partial disruptions to the cartel's activities do not qualify for a YES resolution. If no such official declaration meeting these criteria is made by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither the FDA approve MDMA as a therapy for PTSD by August 2024 nor Mexican authorities declare the dismantling of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if neither of the following occurs: (a) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. The approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically be for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD, not for any other condition or use. If such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly approves or accelerates the approval before August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. (b) Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) make an official public declaration by July 31, 2024, stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources). The declaration should indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. Mere arrests of individual members or partial disruptions to the cartel's activities do not qualify for a YES resolution. If such an official declaration meeting these criteria is made by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is there a possibility that by August 2024, the FDA will authorize MDMA for PTSD treatment or that Mexican officials will announce the disbandment of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if at least one of the following conditions is met: (a) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) formally sanctions MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for therapeutic use in treating Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. This approval must be verified through an official statement from the FDA and reported by a minimum of two credible news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The endorsement must pertain specifically to the application of MDMA for PTSD treatment, excluding any other uses or conditions. If such approval is not granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly denies or postpones the approval past August 31, 2024, the inquiry will be marked as negative. (b) By July 31, 2024, Mexican authorities (including federal law enforcement or senior government officials) issue a formal public statement declaring that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or substantially neutralized as a criminal entity. This declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news agencies (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or prominent Mexican news outlets). The statement should reflect a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership, operations, or its capacity to operate as a unified criminal organization. Simple arrests of individual members or minor disruptions in the cartel's activities will not suffice for a positive resolution. If no such declaration that meets these standards is made by July 31, 2024, the inquiry will be deemed negative.

question.title: Will the Mexican economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Mexican economy does not enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

not_P.title: Will the Mexican economy enter a recession by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Mexican economy enters a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

para_P.title: Will Mexico's economy steer clear of a recession before July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if the Mexican economy does not face a recession by July 31, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a recession is characterized by two successive quarters of negative GDP growth as indicated by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. Conversely, the question will resolve as NO if the Mexican economy undergoes two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

question.title: Will Sony Corporation resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will Sony Corporation not resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if Sony Corporation does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the continuation of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If such a resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if a significant strike does occur, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Sony Corporation come to an agreement to end a significant workers' strike by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if Sony Corporation successfully negotiates with its unionized workforce, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For a valid resolution:

1. The strike must involve a considerable number of employees from Sony Corporation (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must continue for a minimum duration of one week.
3. Confirmation of the resolution must come from official announcements made by both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
4. The outcome must be reported by no fewer than two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If a resolution that meets all these stipulations is not reached by the designated date, or if no significant strike occurs, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Will either the Mexican economy avoid a recession by July 2024 or Sony Corporation resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if at least one of the following occurs:

(a) The Mexican economy does not enter a recession by July 31, 2024. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If neither of these conditions is met, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither the Mexican economy avoid a recession by July 2024 nor Sony Corporation resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if neither of the following occurs:

(a) The Mexican economy enters a recession by July 31, 2024. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the continuation of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If either of these conditions is met, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible for the Mexican economy to evade a recession by July 2024 or for Sony Corporation to settle a significant labor strike by July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry resolves as YES if at least one of the following takes place:

(a) The Mexican economy avoids entering a recession by July 31, 2024. A recession is characterized as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The inquiry resolves as NO if the Mexican economy undergoes two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation comes to a resolution with unionized workers, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be deemed valid:
   1. The strike must involve a significant number of Sony Corporation employees (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must persist for a minimum of one week.
   3. The resolution must be verified by official announcements from both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by no fewer than two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If neither of these criteria is satisfied, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

not_P.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage not exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, does not exceed 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate exceeds 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must not surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

para_P.title: Will the mean interest rate for a 15-year mortgage go beyond 5.5% by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, at any time in August 2024, the mean interest rate for a 15-year fixed mortgage, as documented by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, surpasses 5.5%. The interest rate must be validated by official publications from Freddie Mac or credible financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the interest rate does not exceed 5.5% at any moment during August 2024, the answer will be NO. To clarify, the rate must go above 5.5%, not just match it.

question.title: Will Nevada maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

not_P.title: Will Nevada not maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada is reduced below $11 per hour. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage remains at $11 per hour or higher at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

para_P.title: Will the $11 hourly minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada be upheld until July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, on July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada is still set at $11 per hour or more. The wage level must be verified through official announcements from the state of Nevada or through reports from at least two credible news outlets (like Associated Press, Reuters, or prominent national newspapers). If the wage is lowered to below $11 per hour at any time before the resolution date, the answer will be NO. In this context, 'fast food employees' refers to workers in fast food establishments as defined by Nevada state regulations.

para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if at least one of the following conditions is met: (a) At any time during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as documented by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, is greater than 5.5%. question.title: Will PepsiCo report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will PepsiCo report no increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo does not report an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The lack of increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should not be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If such an increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports an increase in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will there be a rise in North American demand for PepsiCo's Tostitos brand?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo indicates a rise in North American demand for its Tostitos brand in comparison to the demand noted in the second quarter of 2023. The increase must be validated through official earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and covered by a minimum of two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The rise in demand should be clearly articulated or strongly suggested in the company's financial disclosures or official announcements. If no such rise is reported by the given date, or if PepsiCo indicates a continued drop or stagnation in Tostitos demand in North America, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will Tennessee hold a referendum on labor laws by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the state of Tennessee officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on reforming labor laws in the state. The referendum must be officially announced by the Tennessee Secretary of State or other appropriate state election authority, and must be scheduled to take place on or before August 31, 2024. The referendum question must directly address the issue of labor laws. This question will resolve as NO if no such referendum is officially announced or conducted by the specified date. Note that merely gathering signatures for a potential referendum does not qualify for a YES resolution; the actual referendum must be scheduled or held within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of Australia announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. question.title: Will Google resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Google reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Google and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will New York hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the New York state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if:

1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it takes place within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will Alibaba Group resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?

The plan must be part of a state-wide initiative, not limited to specific institutions or pilot programs. question.title: Will another U.S. state implement a 72-hour waiting period for voting registration by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, at least one additional U.S. state (other than Maine and those that already have such measures) implements a mandatory 72-hour waiting period for voting registration. The implementation must be confirmed through official state legislation or government announcements, and reported by at least two major national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, CNN, Fox News, or MSNBC). The waiting period must specifically be 72 hours; longer or shorter periods do not qualify. If no additional state adopts such a measure by the resolution date, or if the implementations are for different waiting periods, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will no additional U.S. state implement a 72-hour waiting period for voting registration by August 2024?

para_P.title: Will any other state in the U.S. establish a 72-hour delay for voter registration by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, at least one more U.S. state (excluding Maine and those already having similar laws) enacts a compulsory 72-hour delay for voter registration. The waiting period must be exactly 72 hours; any longer or shorter durations are not acceptable. question.title: Will U.S. previously occupied home sales increase for three consecutive months by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are three consecutive months where sales of previously occupied homes in the U.S. show an increase compared to the previous month. The data must be verified by reputable sources such as the National Association of Realtors or other widely recognized real estate market analysts. The increases must be reported in terms of seasonally adjusted annual rates. If no such consecutive monthly increases are reported by the resolution date, or if only one or two months show an increase, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the French economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the French economy does not enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies of France. The question resolves as NO if the French economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

not_P.title: Will the French economy enter a recession by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the French economy does enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies of France. The question resolves as NO if the French economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

para_P.title: Can the French economy steer clear of a recession before July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by the end of July 2024, the French economy has not fallen into a recession. A recession, for the purposes of this question, is characterized by two successive quarters of negative GDP growth as documented by the National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies of France. Conversely, the answer will be NO if the French economy undergoes two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time from October 1, 2023, to July 31, 2024.

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Mexico's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Mexico's preferred inflation measure reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Central Bank of Mexico or a relevant Mexican government agency and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, El Financiero). If no such increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame.

not_P.title: Will the Central Bank of Mexico's preferred inflation measure not show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Mexico's preferred inflation measure does not report a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The lack of an increase must be officially published by the Central Bank of Mexico or a relevant Mexican government agency and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, El Financiero). If such an increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame.

para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if the preferred inflation metric of the Central Bank of Mexico reflects a month-over-month rise exceeding 0.5% in any single month from October 2023 through July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially announced by the Central Bank of Mexico or a pertinent Mexican government body and reported by at least two credible financial news outlets (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or El Financiero). If no such increase is documented during this timeframe, the inquiry will be considered negative. It is important to note that this question pertains specifically to month-over-month changes, rather than year-over-year or any other duration.

The question resolves as NO if the French economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Central Bank of Mexico or a relevant Mexican government agency and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, El Financiero). question.title: Will Kamala Harris announce her running mate at a rally in Los Angeles by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in Los Angeles, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally. If Harris does not make such an announcement at a Los Angeles rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will Kamala Harris not announce her running mate at a rally in Los Angeles by August 2024?

If Harris makes such an announcement at a Los Angeles rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that Kamala Harris will reveal her choice for a running mate at a rally in Los Angeles before the end of August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly discloses her running mate for the forthcoming election during a rally taking place in Los Angeles, California. question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Tim Scott publicly retracts or significantly alters his statement regarding Joe Biden's position on criminal justice reform. question.title: Will the NFL settle the 'Sunday Ticket' antitrust case for less than $4.7 billion by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if by July 31, 2024, the NFL reaches a settlement in the 'Sunday Ticket' antitrust case for an amount less than $4,707,259,944. The settlement must be officially confirmed through court documents or public announcements by involved parties. If no such settlement is reached by the resolution date, or if the settlement amount is equal to or more than $4.7 billion, the question resolves as NO. question.title: Will Illinois maintain its current legal stance on abortion access by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Illinois Supreme Court has not reversed or significantly altered its 2023 decision that struck down state laws regulating abortion providers more strictly than other health care providers and banned a common second-trimester procedure. The question will resolve as NO if, by July 31, 2024, the Illinois Supreme Court has reversed this decision, reinstated stricter regulations on abortion providers, or reinstated the ban on the second-trimester procedure. The resolution will be based on official court decisions or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post).

not_P.title: Will Illinois not maintain its current legal stance on abortion access by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Illinois Supreme Court has reversed or significantly altered its 2023 decision that struck down state laws regulating abortion providers more strictly than other health care providers and banned a common second-trimester procedure. para_P.title: Will Illinois uphold its existing legal position regarding abortion access by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Illinois Supreme Court has not overturned or substantially modified its 2023 ruling that invalidated state laws imposing stricter regulations on abortion providers compared to other healthcare providers and prohibited a widely used second-trimester procedure. Conversely, the question will resolve as NO if, by July 31, 2024, the Illinois Supreme Court has overturned this ruling, reinstated stricter regulations on abortion providers, or reinstated the prohibition on the second-trimester procedure. The final determination will rely on official court rulings or credible reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post).

question.title: Will the HHS's rule on telehealth services be enacted by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a new Department of Health and Human Services rule specifically targeting the regulation of telehealth services is enacted through legal or administrative means. Enactment must be confirmed through official announcements by the HHS, court rulings, or other authoritative legal sources, and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, The Wall Street Journal, or The New York Times). The rule must be effective and not merely proposed or pending. If no such rule is enacted and in effect by August 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the HHS's rule on telehealth services not be enacted by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, no new Department of Health and Human Services rule specifically targeting the regulation of telehealth services is enacted through legal or administrative means. question.title: Will Spain's IBEX 35 index reach or exceed 10,000 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, at any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, Spain's IBEX 35 index reaches or exceeds 10,000 points. The 10,000 point level is chosen as a representative value that the index might have been at before a significant drop. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the Bolsa de Madrid. If the index does not reach 10,000 points during this period, the question resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 10,000 points.

question.title: Will the African Union declare the current mpox outbreak over by August 2024?

The duty must be specifically aimed at solar panels that are manufactured in China and not part of a wider duty on all goods from China or all electronic products. question.title: Will either Google reach a settlement with the UK data protection authority or the European Commission implement a significant tariff on Chinese-made solar panels by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs by August 31, 2024: (a) Google and the UK data protection authority reach a formal settlement agreement regarding a fine imposed on Google for alleged data protection violations. The settlement must be confirmed by official statements from either party or reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or major national newspapers). The settlement should specifically address the fine imposed by the UK authority on Google. Appeals, ongoing negotiations, or partial settlements do not qualify for a YES resolution. (b) The European Commission officially implements a tariff of 50% or higher on imports of Chinese-made solar panels. The implementation must be confirmed by official European Commission announcements and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist). The tariff must be specifically targeted at solar panels manufactured in China and not part of a broader tariff on all Chinese goods or all electronic goods. If neither of these events occurs by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will an enforceable ethics code for U.S. Congress members be established by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, an enforceable ethics code specifically for U.S. Congress members is officially adopted by the United States government. The adoption must be confirmed by at least two major, reputable news outlets (such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Associated Press). The ethics code must be legally binding and applicable to all sitting Congress members. It should outline clear standards of conduct and mechanisms for enforcement. If no such code meeting these criteria is established and officially adopted by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Note that mere proposals or discussions about such a code do not qualify for a YES resolution; the code must be formally adopted and enforceable.

not_P.title: Will no enforceable ethics code for U.S. Congress members be established by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, no enforceable ethics code specifically for U.S. Congress members is officially adopted by the United States government. The ethics code must not be legally binding and applicable to all sitting Congress members. It should not outline clear standards of conduct and mechanisms for enforcement. If such a code meeting these criteria is established and officially adopted by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Note that mere proposals or discussions about such a code do not qualify for a YES resolution; the code must be formally adopted and enforceable.

para_P.title: Will a legally binding ethics code for members of the U.S. Congress be put in place by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, a legally binding ethics code specifically for members of the U.S. Congress is officially enacted by the United States government. Confirmation of this adoption must come from at least two major, credible news organizations (such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Associated Press). The ethics code must be enforceable and relevant to all current Congress members, detailing explicit standards of behavior and enforcement procedures. If such a code that meets these requirements is not established and officially enacted by the deadline, the resolution will be NO. It is important to note that simply having proposals or discussions regarding such a code will not suffice for a YES resolution; the code must be formally enacted and enforceable.

question.title: Will Michigan hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Michigan officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a positive resolution:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Michigan state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if:

1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it takes place within the specified timeframe.

not_P.title: Will Michigan not hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?

The question will resolve as NO if:

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it does not take place within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will Sara Lee issue a recall of packaged meats due to a listeria outbreak by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Sara Lee officially announces a recall of any of its packaged meat products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must be confirmed through at least one of the following sources:

1. An official announcement on Sara Lee's website or social media channels
2. A press release from Sara Lee
3. An announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Sara Lee recall
4. Reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources

The recall must explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal. If no such recall meeting these criteria is announced by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO.

The recall must clearly state listeria as the cause for the withdrawal of the products. If no such recall that meets these conditions is made public by the specified deadline, the outcome will be NO.

question.title: Will the E. coli outbreak tied to lettuce result in more than 10 confirmed deaths by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, there are official reports confirming more than 10 deaths attributed to the E. coli outbreak linked to lettuce from a specific producer. Official confirmation must come from credible sources such as the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) or equivalent health authorities, and be reported by at least two reputable news outlets. The death toll must be specifically linked to this outbreak and not include deaths from unrelated E. coli cases. If the death toll remains at 10 or fewer by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, only deaths directly attributed to this specific outbreak will be counted.

question.title: Will Sony Corporation resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will Sony Corporation not resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if Sony Corporation does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the continuation of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If such a resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if a significant strike does occur, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Sony Corporation come to an agreement to end a significant workers' strike by July 2024?
para_P.body:

1. The strike must involve a considerable number of employees from Sony Corporation (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must continue for a minimum of one week.
3. The conclusion must be verified by official announcements from both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
4. The conclusion must be reported by no fewer than two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If such a resolution that fulfills all these conditions is not reached by the stated date, or if no significant strike takes place, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Will the United States maintain a 100% tariff on Chinese-made machinery through August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, as of August 31, 2024, the United States continues to impose a 100% tariff on imports of Chinese-made machinery. The existence and rate of the tariff must be verifiable through official U.S. government sources (such as the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce) and corroborated by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times). If the tariff is reduced below 100% or completely removed at any point up to and including August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Temporary suspensions or waivers of the tariff that are explicitly stated to be temporary and do not permanently alter the 100% rate will not affect the resolution of this question.

not_P.title: Will the United States not maintain a 100% tariff on Chinese-made machinery through August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, as of August 31, 2024, the United States does not continue to impose a 100% tariff on imports of Chinese-made machinery. The existence and rate of the tariff must be verifiable through official U.S. government sources (such as the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce) and corroborated by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times). If the tariff is maintained at 100% or is not reduced or removed at any point up to and including August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Temporary suspensions or waivers of the tariff that are explicitly stated to be temporary and do not permanently alter the 100% rate will not affect the resolution of this question.

para_P.title: Will the United States uphold a full 100% tariff on machinery imported from China until August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by August 31, 2024, the United States is still enforcing a 100% tariff on the importation of machinery produced in China. The presence and percentage of the tariff must be confirmable through official U.S. government documentation (such as that from the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce) and validated by a minimum of two credible news outlets (for instance, Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, or The New York Times). Should the tariff be decreased below 100% or entirely eliminated at any time up to and including August 31, 2024, the response to this question will be NO. Temporary halts or exemptions of the tariff that are explicitly labeled as temporary and do not permanently change the 100% rate will not influence the outcome of this question.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike by July 2024, or (b) The United States maintains a 100% tariff on Chinese-made machinery through August 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs:

(a) Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For this to resolve as YES:
   1. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Sony Corporation workers.
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, this part resolves as NO.

(b) The United States continues to impose a 100% tariff on imports of Chinese-made machinery as of August 31, 2024. For this to resolve as YES:
   1. The existence and rate of the tariff must be verifiable through official U.S. government sources (such as the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce).
   2. It must be corroborated by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times).
   If the tariff is reduced below 100% or completely removed at any point up to and including August 31, 2024, this part resolves as NO. Temporary suspensions or waivers that do not permanently alter the 100% rate will not affect the resolution.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) Sony Corporation does not resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024, nor (b) The United States does not maintain a 100% tariff on Chinese-made machinery through August 2024?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if neither of the following occurs:

(a) Sony Corporation does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the continuation of a significant strike beyond July 31, 2024. For this to resolve as YES:
   1. The strike must involve fewer than 1,000 Sony Corporation workers, or it must last for less than one week, or the resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union, or it must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If such a resolution meeting none of these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if a significant strike does not occur, this part resolves as YES.

(b) The United States does not continue to impose a 100% tariff on imports of Chinese-made machinery as of August 31, 2024. For this to resolve as YES:
   1. The existence and rate of the tariff must not be verifiable through official U.S. government sources (such as the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce).
   2. It must not be corroborated by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times).
   If the tariff is not reduced below 100% or completely removed at any point up to and including August 31, 2024, this part resolves as YES. Temporary suspensions or waivers that do not permanently alter the 100% rate will not affect the resolution.

para_P.title: Is it possible that one of the following happens: (a) Sony Corporation settles a significant labor strike by July 2024, or (b) The United States keeps a 100% tariff on machinery imported from China until August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be considered YES if one of the following takes place:

(a) Sony Corporation successfully negotiates with unionized employees, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For this to be marked as YES:
   1. The strike must involve a minimum of 1,000 workers from Sony Corporation.
   2. The strike should continue for at least one week.
   3. The agreement must be verified by official announcements from both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
   4. The agreement must be reported by no fewer than two credible international news outlets (such as Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If such a resolution that meets all these conditions is not reached by the given date, or if no significant strike occurs, this section will resolve as NO.

(b) The United States persists in enforcing a 100% tariff on Chinese-made machinery as of August 31, 2024. For this to be marked as YES:
   1. The presence and percentage of the tariff must be confirmable through official U.S. government documentation (like the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the U.S. Department of Commerce).
   2. This must be validated by at least two reputable news organizations (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times).
   If the tariff is lowered below 100% or completely lifted at any time up to and including August 31, 2024, this portion will resolve as NO. Temporary suspensions or exemptions that do not permanently change the 100% rate will not impact the resolution.

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate remain at or above 13.25% in August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate is reported to be at or above 13.25% at any point during August 2024. Confirmation must come from official Central Bank of Brazil announcements or at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Folha de S.Paulo). If the rate is reported to have decreased below 13.25% and remains below this level throughout August 2024, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate not remain at or above 13.25% in August 2024?

If the rate is reported to have remained at or above 13.25% throughout August 2024, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Brazil's Central Bank's Selic interest rate stay at or exceed 13.25% in August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed TRUE if the Selic interest rate set by Brazil's Central Bank is documented to be at or over 13.25% at any time during August 2024. Verification must come from official announcements by the Central Bank of Brazil or at least two credible financial news outlets (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, Folha de S.Paulo). If the rate is recorded to have fallen below 13.25% and stays below this threshold for the entire month of August 2024, the inquiry will be considered FALSE.

question.title: Will Argentine agricultural workers remain on strike through August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, agricultural workers in Argentina are still on strike or have not fully resumed normal operations following any current labor dispute. The status of the strike or work resumption must be confirmed by official statements from agricultural organizations, the unions representing the workers, or the Argentine government, and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Clarín, La Nación, or Reuters). If the workers have fully returned to work and normal operations have resumed before or during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. Partial returns to work or limited operations do not count as a full resolution of the strike.

not_P.title: Will Argentine agricultural workers not remain on strike through August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, agricultural workers in Argentina are not on strike and have fully resumed normal operations following any current labor dispute. If the workers have not fully returned to work and normal operations have not resumed before or during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. Partial returns to work or limited operations do not count as a full resolution of the strike.

para_P.title: Will agricultural laborers in Argentina continue their strike until August 2024?

If the workers have entirely returned to their jobs and normal operations have been reinstated before or during August 2024, the answer will be NO. Any partial returns to work or restricted operations do not qualify as a complete resolution of the strike.

question.title: Will the Indonesian economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Indonesian economy does not enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by Statistics Indonesia. The question resolves as NO if the Indonesian economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

not_P.title: Will the Indonesian economy enter a recession by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Indonesian economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by Statistics Indonesia. The question resolves as NO if the Indonesian economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

para_P.title: Can Indonesia's economy steer clear of a recession by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by July 31, 2024, Indonesia's economy does not fall into a recession. A recession is characterized for this question as two successive quarters of declining GDP growth as reported by Statistics Indonesia. Conversely, the answer will be NO if Indonesia's economy undergoes two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time from October 1, 2023, to July 31, 2024.

question.title: Will the World Health Organization declare the current measles outbreak over by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares the ongoing measles outbreak over by August 31, 2024. The declaration must be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The outbreak referred to in this question is the one that prompted heightened public health responses globally. If no such declaration ending the outbreak is made by the resolution date, or if the WHO extends the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will the World Health Organization not declare the current measles outbreak over by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if the World Health Organization (WHO) does not officially declare the ongoing measles outbreak over by August 31, 2024. The declaration must not be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The outbreak referred to in this question is the one that prompted heightened public health responses globally. If such a declaration ending the outbreak is made by the resolution date, or if the WHO does not extend the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

This announcement must be validated through official communications from the WHO or reports from a minimum of three credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The epidemic in question is the one that led to increased public health measures worldwide. If there is no such announcement ending the epidemic by the resolution date, or if the WHO prolongs the emergency status past August 31, 2024, the inquiry will be answered with NO.

question.title: Will a South Korean battery company's factory project in Ohio be canceled by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, it is confirmed that the South Korean lithium-ion battery company's plan to build a factory in Ohio has been officially canceled. Confirmation must come from official statements by the company, the state of Ohio, or at least two credible news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The cancellation must be a complete termination of the project, not just a delay or modification. If the project is still ongoing, under review, or has not been officially canceled by this date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'cancellation' means the company has formally withdrawn its plans or the state has definitively rejected the project.

not_P.title: Will a South Korean battery company's factory project in Ohio not be canceled by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, it is confirmed that the South Korean lithium-ion battery company's plan to build a factory in Ohio has not been officially canceled. Confirmation must come from official statements by the company, the state of Ohio, or at least two credible news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The project must still be ongoing, under review, or not officially canceled by this date. For the purpose of this question, 'not canceled' means the company has not formally withdrawn its plans and the state has not definitively rejected the project.

para_P.title: Is there a possibility that the factory initiative of a South Korean battery manufacturer in Ohio will be scrapped by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by August 31, 2024, it is verified that the South Korean lithium-ion battery manufacturer's intention to establish a factory in Ohio has been officially abandoned. Verification must be obtained from official announcements by the company, the state of Ohio, or at least two reliable news outlets (such as the Associated Press, Reuters, or prominent national newspapers). The abandonment must represent a full cancellation of the project, rather than merely a postponement or alteration. If the initiative is still in progress, under consideration, or has not been officially scrapped by this deadline, the inquiry will be answered with a NO. For the purposes of this inquiry, 'scrapping' indicates that the company has officially retracted its plans or the state has categorically declined the project.

question.title: Will South Korea's KOSPI index reach or exceed 3,500 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, at any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, South Korea's KOSPI index reaches or exceeds 3,500 points. The 3,500 point level is chosen as a representative value that the index might have been at before a significant drop. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the Korea Exchange. If the index does not reach 3,500 points during this period, the question resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 3,500 points.

not_P.title: Will South Korea's KOSPI index not reach or exceed 3,500 points by August 2024?

question.title: Will Andrew Bailey remain as Governor of the Bank of England through July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if Andrew Bailey is still serving as the Governor of the Bank of England on July 31, 2024. If he is no longer serving as Governor by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, any interim or acting Governor appointments will not be considered as Bailey remaining in the position.

question.title: Will a government-developed AI system be reported for spreading election misinformation by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, there are credible reports or official warnings from election officials, government authorities, or reputable news organizations stating that a government-developed AI system is spreading election misinformation. For the purpose of this question, 'election misinformation' refers to false or misleading information about election processes, candidates, or results. Credible reports should come from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US networks), or peer-reviewed studies published in reputable journals. The reports or warnings must specifically mention the government-developed AI system and its role in spreading election misinformation. If no such reports or warnings are issued by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will a government-developed AI system not be reported for spreading election misinformation by August 2024?

question.title: Will Russia's Federation Council pass a major economic reform bill opposed by President Putin by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Russia's Federation Council passes a major economic reform bill that is explicitly opposed by President Vladimir Putin or his administration. To qualify:

1. The bill must be related to economic policy, such as fiscal spending, taxation, or monetary policy.
2. It must be passed by the Federation Council, regardless of whether it becomes law.
3. The opposition from President Putin or his administration must be clearly reported by at least two major international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, Financial Times).
4. The bill must be described as 'major' or 'significant' by these news sources in terms of its potential impact on the Russian economy.

If no such bill is passed by the Federation Council by August 31, 2024, or if a bill is passed but does not meet all the above criteria, the question resolves as NO.
